<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh';
	}
</script>

	<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v23.1 (Yoast SEO v23.1) - https://yoast.com/wordpress/plugins/seo/ -->
	<title>Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh HTTP Response Header</title>
	<meta name="description" content="We detail a rare phishing mechanism using a refresh entry in the HTTP response header for stealth redirects to malicious pages, affecting finance and government sectors. We detail a rare phishing mechanism using a refresh entry in the HTTP response header for stealth redirects to malicious pages, affecting finance and government sectors." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh/" />
	<meta property="og:locale" content="en_US" />
	<meta property="og:type" content="article" />
	<meta property="og:title" content="Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh HTTP Response Header" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="We detail a rare phishing mechanism using a refresh entry in the HTTP response header for stealth redirects to malicious pages, affecting finance and government sectors. We detail a rare phishing mechanism using a refresh entry in the HTTP response header for stealth redirects to malicious pages, affecting finance and government sectors." />
	<meta property="og:url" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh/" />

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/business-email-compromise/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Yu Zhang"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Zeyu You"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Wei Wang"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="JavaScript,phishing"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh HTTP Response Header","name":"Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh HTTP Response Header","description":"We detail a rare phishing mechanism using a refresh entry in the HTTP response header for stealth redirects to malicious pages, affecting finance and government sectors.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh\/","datePublished":"September 11, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers observed many large-scale phishing campaigns in 2024 that used a refresh entry in the HTTP response header. From May-July we detected around 2,000 malicious URLs daily that were associated with campaigns of this type.\r\n\r\nUnlike other phishing webpage distribution behavior through HTML content, these attacks use the response header sent by a server, which occurs before the processing of the HTML content. Malicious links direct the browser to automatically refresh or reload a webpage immediately, without requiring user interaction.\r\n\r\nAttackers predominantly distribute the malicious URLs in the phishing campaigns via emails. These emails consistently include recipients' email addresses and display spoofed webmail login pages based on the recipients' email domain pre-filled with the users\u2019 information. They largely target people in the global financial sector, well-known internet portals and government domains.\r\n\r\nSince the original and landing URLs are often found under legitimate or compromised domains, it is difficult to spot malicious indicators within a URL string. Furthermore, attackers use personalized approaches that increase the likelihood that they will deceive their victim.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through Advanced URL Filtering (AURL). Besides identifying phishing URLs in the described scenario, AURL extracts patterns from these suspicious URLs and could discover additional phishing websites.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nBusiness Email Compromise (BEC)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHow the Header Refresh Technique Works\r\nPhishing attackers commonly employ a variety of readily available tools and mechanisms to obscure their malicious intent and deceive their victims. We recently observed attackers using header refresh techniques to embed their phishing links and craft convincing email subjects to deceive customers.\r\n\r\nThese malicious links, which have the targeted user\u2019s email address embedded in the refresh field of the HTTP response header, direct the browser to automatically refresh or reload a webpage immediately. They do so without requiring user interaction.\r\n\r\nBy carefully mimicking legitimate domains and redirecting victims to official sites, attackers can effectively mask their true objectives and increase the likelihood of successful credential theft. These tactics highlight the sophisticated strategies attackers use to avoid detection and exploit unsuspecting targets.\r\n\r\nTo see how the header refresh technique works, we will describe an example. In one phishing attempt we observed, the refresh field of the response header is:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBelow, Figure 1 shows the refresh entry in the HTTP response headers in response to the original URL, as seen using DevTools in Google Chrome.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136707\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Example of an HTTP response header shown in DevTools.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe original and landing URLs are often found under legitimate or compromised domains and hosts, a technique that\u2019s often effective in concealing malicious URL strings. Additionally, attackers frequently use legitimate domains that offer URL shortening, tracking or campaign marketing services.\r\n\r\nMany attackers also employ deep linking to dynamically generate content that appears tailored to the individual target. By using parameters in the URL, they pre-fill sections of a form, enhancing the credibility of the phishing attempt.\r\n\r\nThis personalized approach increases the likelihood that the attacker will deceive the victim. Attackers have exploited this mechanism because it enables them to load phishing content with minimum effort while concealing the malicious content.\r\nExample of Header Refresh Phishing Attacks\r\nTo trick their targets and steal their credentials, malicious links in these attacks consistently include an organization\u2019s email address and display an email login page pre-filled with victims\u2019 information.\r\n\r\nFigure 2 returns to the example above, showing a related phishing page found on July 14, 2024.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136709\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Phishing page, sent through a refresh entry in an HTTP response header.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nTable 1 below shows the original URL and the final URL from the phishing page in Figure 2. When clicking the original URL from the phishing email, the server hosting that original URL used a refresh entry in the HTTP response headers, as described in the previous section. This is used to redirect traffic to the final URL under the domain hk6.8ik8rq[.]ru.\r\n\r\nThis URL is the final address for the phishing page. In many cases, we find a landing URL between the original address and the final one in this chain.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDate\r\nOriginal URL\r\nFinal URL (Header Link)\r\n\r\n\r\nJuly 14, 2024\r\nhxxp[:]\/\/impactchd[.]in\/content\/bing\/ghjkj\/1kdeyl61ahaub\/[Base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/hk6.8ik8rq[.]ru\/hk6\/#[recipient's email address]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Example of a phishing URL chain.\r\nPhishing Campaign Example\r\nFrom June 20-21, 2024, we observed large-scale phishing campaigns through emails predominantly targeting large corporations in Korea. We also saw campaigns targeting government agencies and schools in the U.S. One particular campaign was notable for its use of emails originating from the same source IP address at 195.19.93[.]5 and the same spoofed sender addresses of 2127394249@businessimageprint[.]com or 2127394249@docusign[.]com. Attackers varied the recipients across multiple domains ending with [.]gov, [.]edu and [.]com.\r\n\r\nThe most common email subject was Complete with DocuSign: ACH\/EFT FORM ***. URLs embedded within these emails commonly contained a subpath of sf_rand_string_lowercase6. Figure 3 shows the campaign trending and Figure 4 shows the percentages of targeted industries.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136711\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. sf_rand_string_lowercase6 phishing campaign trending.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136713\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 4. Email domain industry distributions on sf_rand_string_lowercase6 campaign.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOver 34% of the attacks targeted people in the business-and-economy sector. Nearly 30% of the targets were from governments and educational institutions.\r\n\r\nAttackers delivered the malicious links through header refresh URLs containing targeted recipients email addresses. Consistent with the email recipient\u2019s domain, the final page would be automatically loaded with malicious link content when the victim clicks the link in the email body.\r\n\r\nUpon landing on the phishing webpage, victims were presented with a login page requesting their credentials. An example of one of the campaigns is detailed on LinkedIn in our Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence post.\r\nLarge Phishing Campaigns Statistics\r\nPhishing attacks target a large number of users in various organizations, encompassing numerous large-scale campaigns. Table 2 shows the top domains for the initial URLs used by large campaigns in the past three months, and Figure 5 shows the frequency of those top domains.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nURL Domain\r\nURL Domain Category\r\nNumber of Detections\r\nMost Frequent Date\r\nTop Targeted Industry\r\n\r\n\r\nonelink[.]me\r\nComputer-and-internet-info\r\n5,537\r\nMay 10, 2024\r\nFinancial-services\r\n\r\n\r\ngo[.]link\u00a0\r\nBusiness-and-economy\r\n5,374\r\nMay 6, 2024\r\nNews\r\n\r\n\r\nspeedpython[.]com\r\nMalware\r\n3,027\r\nMay 14, 2024\r\nGovernment\r\n\r\n\r\nclub-os[.]com\r\nBusiness-and-economy\r\n2,384\r\nApril 12, 2024\r\nBusiness-and-economy (mostly in Japan)\r\n\r\n\r\nguide-orientation[.]tn\r\nEducational-institutions\r\n1,888\r\nJuly 2, 2024\r\nBusiness-and-economy\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. Examples of large campaigns from April 12-July 7, 2024.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136716\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 5. Number of detections for initial phishing URLs from top five domains, April 14 through July 7, 2024.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nDifferent domains appeared during various time periods. Some campaigns, particularly those using malicious URLs under the domain onelink[.]me, have continued for a prolonged period. Figure 5 above shows the campaign had a peak on May 10, 2024, and lasted for about one month. The campaign targeted over 3,000 victims across more than 500 organizations.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, campaigns associated with the go[.]link domain experienced a sudden surge at the beginning of May, with over 5,000 malicious URLs detected. Domain club-os[.]com peaked on April 12, 2024, but persisted from late April to the present. In late June, we noticed a new campaign under guide-orientation[.]tn, which occurred most on July 2, 2024.\r\nAffected Users\r\nPhishing attacks aim to steal email login credentials from people at various organizations. Figure 6 shows the distribution of industries from our total detections in this wave of attacks.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136718\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 6. Percentages of targeted industries from our total detections.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOver 36% of the attacks largely targeted people in the global business-and-economy sector. The second-largest sector is financial services, including global banks and financial service companies. We also observed that phishing emails were sent to users of well known internet portals and government domains.\r\n\r\nSince many companies use Microsoft\/Outlook for their email service, the phishing pages frequently imitate the webmail login page, such as the Outlook webmail login portal shown below in Figure 7.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136720\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. A phishing page impersonating the Outlook webmail login portal.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs shown in Table 3, the original URL of the above example was under domain cices[.]org but landed on a different domain dominicanmidia[.]com. When the victim clicked this URL, it reloaded a webpage under sirius-maritime[.]com and showed a fake Outlook webmail login page prefilled with the user's email address (associated with a technology company). The attack was designed to trick the user into entering their password on the fake page, exposing their credentials to the attacker.\r\n\r\nThe page allowed the victim to enter their password three times at most, capturing these attempts, then redirecting to the official site office[.]com. We also saw similar attacks targeting other recipients associated with different companies.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDate\r\nOriginal URL\r\nLanding URL\r\nFinal URL\u00a0(Header Link)\r\n\r\n\r\nMay 21, 2024\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/www[.]cices[.]org\/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/obld\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/obld\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/sirius-maritime[.]com\/0utl0ok\/?email=[recipient's email address]\r\n\r\n\r\nMay 5, 2024\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/www[.]cices[.]org\/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/dnne\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/dnne\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/sirius-maritime[.]com\/0utl0ok\/?email=[recipient's email address]\r\n\r\n\r\nMay 21, 2024\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/www[.]cices[.]org\/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/crej\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/dominicanmidia[.]com\/\/zres\/rezs\/crej\/\/zres\/rezs\/crej\/\/[base64 string for recipient's email address]\r\nhxxps[:]\/\/sirius-maritime[.]com\/0utl0ok\/?email=[recipient's email address]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 3. Similar phishing attacks on different recipients.\r\nConclusion\r\nIn the additional resources section below, we've listed some examples of phishing webpage distribution behavior through HTML content, specifically through the injection of a malicious URL to the meta field of the HTML file. However, as of August 2024, no literature specifically addresses attacks using a refresh entry in the response header sent by a server that occurs before the server processes the HTML content of the response body.\r\n\r\nThis article documents the frequent use of HTTP refresh fields in HTTP response headers in phishing attacks.\r\n\r\nIn our research, we found no legitimate websites exhibiting this behavior. Although the refresh header can be useful in specific situations like dynamically updating websites, we more commonly see other methods such as JavaScript-based techniques or server-side push technologies like WebSockets.\r\n\r\nUltimately, organizations should be more aware of the potential for malicious use of HTTP refresh headers.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through Advanced URL Filtering. To identify phishing URLs in the described scenario, we analyzed the response headers of websites.\r\n\r\nURLs containing an email address injected into the refresh field were typically flagged as suspicious. We extracted patterns from these suspicious URLs and discovered additional phishing websites.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nWe have compiled a CSV file containing 58 examples of sanitized URL chains from May 1-July 2, 2024. It is available as a file in this GitHub repository.\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tMetaMorph HTML Obfuscation Phishing Attack \u2013 Avanan, Check Point\r\n \tUnit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence post on Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh Header \u2013 Unit 42 on LinkedIn\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/09\/03_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Yu Zhang"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Zeyu You"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Wei Wang"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

#ffffff;--wp--preset--color--pale-pink: #f78da7;--wp--preset--color--vivid-red: #cf2e2e;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-orange: #ff6900;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-amber: #fcb900;--wp--preset--color--light-green-cyan: #7bdcb5;--wp--preset--color--vivid-green-cyan: #00d084;--wp--preset--color--pale-cyan-blue: #8ed1fc;--wp--preset--color--vivid-cyan-blue: #0693e3;--wp--preset--color--vivid-purple: #9b51e0;--wp--preset--gradient--vivid-cyan-blue-to-vivid-purple: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(6,147,227,1) 0%,rgb(155,81,224) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--light-green-cyan-to-vivid-green-cyan: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(122,220,180) 0%,rgb(0,208,130)     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-136700 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">
        <button class="btn__search" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#search" aria-label="search"><i class="ui ui-1"></i></button>
      </div>

      <div id="search" class="collapse d-sm-block col-sm-auto col-12 ml-auto order-3">
        <div class="pt-sm-0 pt-20 pb-sm-0 pb-40 mt-sm-0 mt-n30">
                      <input type="search" placeholder="Search Unit 42" id="innerSearch" class="header__search" value="" required aria-label="Inner Search">
                  </div>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none d-flex ml-auto align-items-center order-5">
        <button class="btn__menu rounded" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#navigation">Menu</button>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</header>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-121229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-121229"><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"><b style="color:#C84727">Under Attack?</b></a></li>
</ul>  </div>
</nav>
<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-136700-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers observed many large-scale phishing campaigns in 2024 that used a refresh entry in the HTTP response header. From May-July we detected around 2,000 malicious URLs daily that were associated with campaigns of this type.</p>
<p>Unlike other phishing webpage distribution behavior through HTML content, these attacks use the response header sent by a server, which occurs before the processing of the HTML content. Malicious links direct the browser to automatically refresh or reload a webpage immediately, without requiring user interaction.</p>
<p>Attackers predominantly distribute the malicious URLs in the phishing campaigns via emails. These emails consistently include recipients' email addresses and display spoofed webmail login pages based on the recipients' email domain pre-filled with the users’ information. They largely target people in the global financial sector, well-known internet portals and government domains.</p>
<p>Since the original and landing URLs are often found under legitimate or compromised domains, it is difficult to spot malicious indicators within a URL string. Furthermore, attackers use personalized approaches that increase the likelihood that they will deceive their victim.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering (AURL)</a>. Besides identifying phishing URLs in the described scenario, AURL extracts patterns from these suspicious URLs and could discover additional phishing websites.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/business-email-compromise/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Business Email Compromise (BEC)</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-136700-_b1g5exh6ur86"></a>How the Header Refresh Technique Works</h2>
<p>Phishing attackers commonly employ a variety of readily available tools and mechanisms to obscure their malicious intent and deceive their victims. We recently observed attackers using <a href="https://blog.quttera.com/post/finding-stopping-malicious-http-redirection/#rec697454762" target="_blank" rel="noopener">header refresh</a> techniques to embed their phishing links and craft convincing email subjects to deceive customers.</p>
<p>These malicious links, which have the targeted user’s email address embedded in the refresh field of the HTTP response header, direct the browser to automatically refresh or reload a webpage immediately. They do so without requiring user interaction.</p>
<p>By carefully mimicking legitimate domains and redirecting victims to official sites, attackers can effectively mask their true objectives and increase the likelihood of successful credential theft. These tactics highlight the sophisticated strategies attackers use to avoid detection and exploit unsuspecting targets.</p>
<p>To see how the header refresh technique works, we will describe an example. In one phishing attempt we observed, the refresh field of the response header is:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-136705" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1.png" alt="Example of the header refresh code. " width="700" height="63" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1.png 1966w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1-786x71.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1-1920x173.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1-768x69.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-308795-136700-1-1536x138.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /></p>
<p>Below, Figure 1 shows the refresh entry in the HTTP response headers in response to the original URL, as seen using DevTools in Google Chrome.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136707" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136707" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136707" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2.png" alt="Screenshot of an HTTP response header shown in DevTools. Highlighted in red is the request URL on top and the refresh URL on the bottom with some text redacted. " width="900" height="405" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2.png 1640w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2-786x354.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2-1556x700.png 1556w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2-768x346.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-311614-136700-2-1536x691.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136707" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Example of an HTTP response header shown in DevTools.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The original and landing URLs are often found under legitimate or compromised domains and hosts, a technique that’s often effective in concealing malicious URL strings. Additionally, attackers frequently use legitimate domains that offer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URL_shortening">URL shortening</a>, tracking or campaign marketing services.</p>
<p>Many attackers also employ <a href="https://www.adjust.com/glossary/deep-linking/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">deep linking</a> to dynamically generate content that appears tailored to the individual target. By using parameters in the URL, they pre-fill sections of a form, enhancing the credibility of the phishing attempt.</p>
<p>This personalized approach increases the likelihood that the attacker will deceive the victim. Attackers have exploited this mechanism because it enables them to load phishing content with minimum effort while concealing the malicious content.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136700-_wven14kmgum2"></a>Example of Header Refresh Phishing Attacks</h3>
<p>To trick their targets and steal their credentials, malicious links in these attacks consistently include an organization’s email address and display an email login page pre-filled with victims’ information.</p>
<p>Figure 2 returns to the example above, showing a related phishing page found on July 14, 2024.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136709" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136709" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136709" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3.png" alt="Screenshot of a phishing page imitating a Microsoft login page requesting a password with the &quot;Sign in&quot; button visible. Some of the information is redacted. " width="900" height="419" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3-786x366.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3-1504x700.png 1504w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3-768x357.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-315182-136700-3-1536x715.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136709" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Phishing page, sent through a refresh entry in an HTTP response header.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Table 1 below shows the original URL and the final URL from the phishing page in Figure 2. When clicking the original URL from the phishing email, the server hosting that original URL used a refresh entry in the HTTP response headers, as described in the previous section. This is used to redirect traffic to the final URL under the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hk6.8ik8rq[.]ru</span>.</p>
<p>This URL is the final address for the phishing page. In many cases, we find a landing URL between the original address and the final one in this chain.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Date</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Original URL</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Final URL (Header Link)</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">July 14, 2024</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp[:]//impactchd[.]in/content/bing/ghjkj/1kdeyl61ahaub/</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[Base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></i></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//hk6.8ik8rq[.]ru/hk6/#</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[recipient's email address]</span></i></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 1. Example of a phishing URL chain.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136700-_vegw7s9dvao8"></a><strong>Phishing Campaign Example</strong></h3>
<p>From June 20-21, 2024, we observed large-scale phishing campaigns through emails predominantly targeting large corporations in Korea. We also saw campaigns targeting government agencies and schools in the U.S. One particular campaign was notable for its use of emails originating from the same source IP address at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">195.19.93[.]5</span> and the same spoofed sender addresses of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2127394249@businessimageprint[.]com</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2127394249@docusign[.]com</span>. Attackers varied the recipients across multiple domains ending with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[.]gov</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[.]edu</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>The most common email subject was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Complete with DocuSign: ACH/EFT FORM ***</span>. URLs embedded within these emails commonly contained a subpath of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sf_rand_string_lowercase6</span>. Figure 3 shows the campaign trending and Figure 4 shows the percentages of targeted industries.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136711" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136711" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136711" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4.png" alt="Bar chart displaying the number of detections by date. The x-axis date range is April 16, 2024 to August 16, 2024. The y-axis measures the number of detections ranging from 0 to 800. Notable peaks include 771 detections on June 6, 2024 before tapering off. The Unit 42 and Palo Alto Networks lockup logo. " width="900" height="354" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4-786x309.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4-1781x700.png 1781w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4-768x302.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-319456-136700-4-1536x604.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136711" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sf_rand_string_lowercase6</span> phishing campaign trending.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_136713" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136713" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136713" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart.png" alt="Pie chart showing the distribution of affected industries. Business and Economy lead with 34.6%, followed by Government at 15.8%, Educational Institutions at 13.7%, Computer and Internet at 8.4%, Health and Medicine at 4.8%, Training and Tools at 3.4%, Parked at 3.1%, and All Other Industries at 16.2%. The Unit 42 and Palo Alto Networks lockup logo. " width="600" height="352" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-749x440.png 749w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1192x700.png 1192w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-768x451.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/chart-1536x902.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136713" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Email domain industry distributions on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sf_rand_string_lowercase6</span> campaign.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Over 34% of the attacks targeted people in the business-and-economy sector. Nearly 30% of the targets were from governments and educational institutions.</p>
<p>Attackers delivered the malicious links through header refresh URLs containing targeted recipients email addresses. Consistent with the email recipient’s domain, the final page would be automatically loaded with malicious link content when the victim clicks the link in the email body.</p>
<p>Upon landing on the phishing webpage, victims were presented with a login page requesting their credentials. An example of one of the campaigns is detailed on LinkedIn in our <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/posts/unit42_phishing-timelythreatintel-unit42threatintel-activity-7218635942796926978-ztlB/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence post</a>.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136700-_ce97cct535j5"></a><strong>Large Phishing Campaigns Statistics</strong></h3>
<p>Phishing attacks target a large number of users in various organizations, encompassing numerous large-scale campaigns. Table 2 shows the top domains for the initial URLs used by large campaigns in the past three months, and Figure 5 shows the frequency of those top domains.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 484px;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 104px;">
<td style="text-align: center; height: 104px;"><b>URL Domain</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; height: 104px;"><b>URL Domain Category</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; height: 104px;"><b>Number of Detections</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; height: 104px;"><b>Most Frequent Date</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; height: 104px;"><b>Top Targeted Industry</b></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">onelink[.]me</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Computer-and-internet-info</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">5,537</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">May 10, 2024</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Financial-services</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">go[.]link </span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Business-and-economy</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">5,374</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">May 6, 2024</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">News</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">speedpython[.]com</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Malware</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3,027</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">May 14, 2024</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Government</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">club-os[.]com</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Business-and-economy</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2,384</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">April 12, 2024</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Business-and-economy (mostly in Japan)</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 83px;">
<td style="height: 83px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">guide-orientation[.]tn</span></td>
<td style="height: 83px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Educational-institutions</span></td>
<td style="height: 83px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">1,888</span></td>
<td style="height: 83px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">July 2, 2024</span></td>
<td style="height: 83px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Business-and-economy</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 2. Examples of large campaigns from April 12-July 7, 2024.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136716" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136716" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136716" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6.png" alt="Line graph showing the number of detections for onelink.me, go.link, speedpython.com, club-os.com, and guide-orientation.tn over a period from April 14 to July 7, 2024. The graph highlights peaks in detections with the highest numbers labeled for clarity across various dates." width="900" height="509" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6.png 1999w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6-778x440.png 778w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6-1237x700.png 1237w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6-768x435.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-328220-136700-6-1536x869.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136716" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Number of detections for initial phishing URLs from top five domains, April 14 through July 7, 2024.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Different domains appeared during various time periods. Some campaigns, particularly those using malicious URLs under the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">onelink[.]me</span>, have continued for a prolonged period. Figure 5 above shows the campaign had a peak on May 10, 2024, and lasted for about one month. The campaign targeted over 3,000 victims across more than 500 organizations.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, campaigns associated with the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">go[.]link</span> domain experienced a sudden surge at the beginning of May, with over 5,000 malicious URLs detected. Domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">club-os[.]com</span> peaked on April 12, 2024, but persisted from late April to the present. In late June, we noticed a new campaign under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">guide-orientation[.]tn</span>, which occurred most on July 2, 2024.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136700-_1kt3toym9zlh"></a><strong>Affected Users</strong></h3>
<p>Phishing attacks aim to steal email login credentials from people at various organizations. Figure 6 shows the distribution of industries from our total detections in this wave of attacks.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136718" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136718" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136718" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7.png" alt="Pie chart displaying the distribution across various industries. The largest segment is Business and Economy at 36.2%, followed by Financial Services at 12.9%. Other sectors include Government at 6.9%, Health and Medicine at 5.7%, and Computer and Internet at 5.4%. All Other Industries is at 32.9%. The Unit 42 and Palo Alto Networks lockup logo. " width="700" height="415" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7-742x440.png 742w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7-1181x700.png 1181w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7-768x455.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-332150-136700-7-1536x911.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136718" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Percentages of targeted industries from our total detections.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Over 36% of the attacks largely targeted people in the global business-and-economy sector. The second-largest sector is financial services, including global banks and financial service companies. We also observed that phishing emails were sent to users of well known internet portals and government domains.</p>
<p>Since many companies use Microsoft/Outlook for their email service, the phishing pages frequently imitate the webmail login page, such as the Outlook webmail login portal shown below in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136720" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136720" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136720" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8.png" alt="Phishing page impersonating Microsoft Outlook login screen with fields for entering username and password, along with a 'Sign in' button. Some parts of the username are redacted. " width="900" height="494" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8-786x431.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8-1277x700.png 1277w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8-768x421.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-336000-136700-8-1536x842.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136720" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. A phishing page impersonating the Outlook webmail login portal.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As shown in Table 3, the original URL of the above example was under domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cices[.]org</span> but landed on a different domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dominicanmidia[.]com</span>. When the victim clicked this URL, it reloaded a webpage under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sirius-maritime[.]com</span> and showed a fake Outlook webmail login page prefilled with the user's email address (associated with a technology company). The attack was designed to trick the user into entering their password on the fake page, exposing their credentials to the attacker.</p>
<p>The page allowed the victim to enter their password three times at most, capturing these attempts, then redirecting to the official site <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">office[.]com</span>. We also saw similar attacks targeting other recipients associated with different companies.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.2192%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><b>Date</b></span></td>
<td style="width: 25.7808%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><b>Original URL</b></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><b>Landing URL</b></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><b>Final URL </b></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><b>(Header Link)</b></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.2192%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12pt;">May 21, 2024</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.7808%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//www[.]cices[.]org/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/obld//</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/obld//<em><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></em></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//sirius-maritime[.]com/0utl0ok/?email</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">=<i>[recipient's email address]</i></span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.2192%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12pt;">May 5, 2024</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.7808%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//www[.]cices[.]org/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/dnne//</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/dnne//</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//sirius-maritime[.]com/0utl0ok/?email=</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 24.2192%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12pt;">May 21, 2024</span></td>
<td style="width: 25.7808%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//www[.]cices[.]org/?wptouch_switch=desktop&amp;redirect=HtTPs[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/crej//</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> string for recipient's email address]</span></span></i></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//dominicanmidia[.]com//zres/rezs/crej//zres/rezs/crej//</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[base64 string for recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
<td style="width: 25%;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//sirius-maritime[.]com/0utl0ok/?email=</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">[recipient's email address]</span></i></span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 3. Similar phishing attacks on different recipients.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136700-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>In the additional resources section below, we've listed some examples of phishing webpage distribution behavior through HTML content, specifically through the injection of a malicious URL to the <a href="https://www.avanan.com/blog/metamorph-html-obfuscation-phishing-attack" target="_blank" rel="noopener">meta field</a> of the HTML file. However, as of August 2024, no literature specifically addresses attacks using a refresh entry in the response header sent by a server that occurs before the server processes the HTML content of the response body.</p>
<p>This article documents the frequent use of HTTP refresh fields in HTTP response headers in phishing attacks.</p>
<p>In our research, we found no legitimate websites exhibiting this behavior. Although the refresh header can be useful in specific situations like dynamically updating websites, we more commonly see other methods such as JavaScript-based techniques or server-side push technologies like WebSockets.</p>
<p>Ultimately, organizations should be more aware of the potential for malicious use of HTTP refresh headers.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136700-_ep355nb204le"></a><strong>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</strong></h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a>. To identify phishing URLs in the described scenario, we analyzed the response headers of websites.</p>
<p>URLs containing an email address injected into the refresh field were typically flagged as suspicious. We extracted patterns from these suspicious URLs and discovered additional phishing websites.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136700-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>We have compiled a CSV file containing 58 examples of sanitized URL chains from May 1-July 2, 2024. It is available as <a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-Threat-Intelligence-Article-Information/blob/main/Phishing_attacks_using_refresh_entries_in_HTTP_response_headers_58_examples.csv" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a file in this GitHub repository</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136700-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.avanan.com/blog/metamorph-html-obfuscation-phishing-attack" target="_blank" rel="noopener">MetaMorph HTML Obfuscation Phishing Attack</a> – Avanan, Check Point</li>
<li><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/posts/unit42_phishing-timelythreatintel-unit42threatintel-activity-7218635942796926978-ztlB/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence post on Phishing Pages Delivered Through Refresh Header</a> – Unit 42 on LinkedIn</li>
</ul>
      
              </div>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/nigeria/" title="Nigeria" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh:related-resources:Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members:Nigeria">Nigeria</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/silverterrier/" title="SilverTerrier" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh:related-resources:Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members:SilverTerrier">SilverTerrier</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/syndicate-orion/" title="Syndicate Orion" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh:related-resources:Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members:Syndicate Orion">Syndicate Orion</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/operation-falcon-ii-silverterrier-nigerian-bec/" title="Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="rare-phishing-page-delivery-header-refresh:related-resources:Operation Falcon II: Unit 42 Helps INTERPOL Identify Nigerian Business Email Compromise Ring Members:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Glowing red skull and crossbones symbol on a highly detailed, illuminated circuit board background, suggesting a concept of cyber threat or computer virus." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/07_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
